author: Henry Alford is a contributing writer to Vanity Fair and the author, most recently, of “Would It Kill You to Stop Doing That? A Modern Guide to Manners.” Circa Now appears monthly.
body:
WE are self-appointed, and we wear the badge of moral righteousness. Some of us police the waterfront, and some of us, the mountaintop. 
 
My jurisdiction is the doorways of public spaces. Why do people congregate there? In the presence of these clogged arteries, I become Lipitor Man. I have made strange beeping noises. I have robotically
title: CIRCA NOW; When the Manners Police Knock

body: Because of an editing error, the Boîte column last Thursday, about Tooker Alley, an artisanal cocktail bar in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, described incorrectly Bar Corvo, a business on the same street. It is a restaurant, not a bar.
title: CORRECTION

body:
PROSPECT HEIGHTS CONDO

 
$579,000 BROOKLYN : 255 Eastern Parkway (between Franklin and Classon Avenues), #A16 A two-bedroom one-bath condo with a washer/dryer in an Art Deco doorman building. Tracey McLean, the Corcoran Group (917) 693-8135; corcoran.com COMMON CHARGE: $532 a month; taxes: $209 a month PROS: Set back from Eastern
title: On the Market

body: IN an unmistakable sign that Prospect Heights has arrived on the Brooklyn scene, the neighborhood now claims not one, but at least two artisanal cocktail bars. The latest even has a retro-sounding name, Tooker Alley, which, it turns out, is named after the Chicago street that led to the Dil Pickle Club, a famed freethinker’s hangout.
title: BOîTE; Tooker Alley

body:
“Do you know what the Brooklyn dog is?” the woman behind the Nathan’s counter says sternly. “It is not a regular dog.”
 
 It is early evening at Barclays Center , in Downtown Brooklyn. Eight and a half miles away, in hurricane-battered Coney Island, the original, nearly-century-old Nathan’s
title: HUNGRY CITY; Brooklyn’s Home-Court Advantage

body:
If the scene at the Barclays Center could be trusted, then the politics of New York sports became increasingly complex on Monday night.
 
It was then, after all, that lovers of local basketball got their first full glimpse of the long-awaited rivalry, an internecine hoops game that should, at least in theory, generate a grudge match as
title: A Nascent Rivalry For the Fans, Too

body:
Drinking beer used to be simple. But the exploding popularity of craft beer over the past several years has changed that, giving beer drinkers a new world of possibilities — and a range of hard decisions. 
 
Predictably, the ever-expanding roster of oatmeal stouts and vanilla porters has been accompanied by the creation of dozens of
title: APP CITY; Having a Beer With a Smartphone

body:
PROSPECT HEIGHTS PENTHOUSE

 
$1,778,000 BROOKLYN : 115 Eastern Parkway (between Underhill and Washington Avenues), #PHB A three-bedroom two-bath duplex penthouse with two terraces, central air-conditioning and a washer/dryer in a co-op building with part-time doormen. Sarah Zelermyer-Diaz (917) 664-2374, Scott Klein (347) 423-9483,
title: On the Market

body:
Its black glass exterior soars high above Fifth Avenue, and its gold-tipped revolving doors have spun the likes of Bruce Willis and Anne Hathaway into its waterfall-splashed atrium.
 
But on Election Day, Trump Tower earned a different sort of distinction: a tiny island of Romneyville amid Manhattan’s deep, blue-state sea. The tower
title: On Island Largely Blue, An Exception: Trump Tower

body:
This is not microwave cooking. These things take time.
 
You don’t just: 1) draw a line around a succulent 22-acre parcel of real estate in the heart of Brooklyn; 2) throw out all the people and knock down all the buildings; 3) shoehorn in an arena that, according to the readers of this newspaper, looks like a rusty turtle or a
title: Places to Drink for Brooklyn’s Toast of the Town

body:
GRADUATE school took Aaron Sherman from New York for two years. He and his wife, Leah Fox, spent a year in Bologna, Italy , and another in Washington, knowing all the while they would return to the city. 
 
“I was thankful that we had two years away,” Ms. Fox said, “because I had been in New York all my life and I
title: THE HUNT; The Wish List: Light, Space, Fireplace

body:
In the best of times, the Knicks made Nelson Ortiz weep.
 
It happened in 1994, when Pat Riley’s squad buckled in Game 7 of the Finals and lost the championship to the Houston Rockets. It happened again in 1999, when the eighth-seeded Knicks returned to the Finals, in fairy-tale fashion, only to get crushed by the San Antonio Spurs.
title: Fans in Brooklyn Have New Shoulder to Cry On

body:
The yellowing of Flatbush Avenue began just before 10 p.m., greeting the area’s revelers as they lumbered out of the neighborhood’s new nerve center with beer on their breath and their team’s logo on their chests.
 
The people jockeyed for curbside position, stretching their open palms into traffic. Terse words were
title: Yellow Taxis, Rare Brooklyn Sightings, Multiply on Event Nights at New Arena

body:
ON a miserable rainy night on the outskirts of Jackson Heights, Queens, a couple of dozen people were gathered for an informal cultural experiment: How do you create a literary community in a place that does not even have a decent English-language bookstore ? 
 
Joseph Goodrich and Honor Molloy entered the local bar anxiously. Mr. Goodrich,
title: Poets Gather in Exile, in Queens

body:
‘JACKIE AND ME’

 
Many feisty preteen boys would rather throw a punch than turn the other cheek. In the play “Jackie and Me,” Joey Stoshack tries both, ultimately finding himself in a fight whose implications go well beyond his schoolyard. Joey, it turns out, has an unusual talent: When he holds a baseball
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: After nine years as the focal point of a pitched confrontation over urban development, power and basketball, the Barclays Center in Brooklyn began its first day of life on Friday with the hip-hop superstar Jay-Z performing at a sold-out concert while activists outside the arena reminded attendees of the unfulfilled promises of the center's
title: For Brooklyn's New Arena, Day 1 Brings Hip-Hop Fans and Protests

body: INSTEAD of peanut M&Ms, think Tumbador's PB&J chocolate bar, handmade in Sunset Park. Instead of Häagen-Dazs, think Blue Marble ice cream . Instead of Tostitos, think Baked in Brooklyn Flatbread Crisps. This is the new Barclays Center, home of the Brooklyn Nets , with food about as local as stadium fare gets. After 10 tumultuous years, including a
title: If Only the Nets Live Up to Their Arena's Food

body: The cookies , chocolates and other confections, mostly from Brooklyn artisans. Admission to the fiesta is $15 for adults, $10 for students and those 65 or older, and free for
title: FOOD STUFF; Enjoying the Heat in Brooklyn

body: THEY talk about it as if it were a force of nature. ''We're bracing ourselves, almost like hurricane preparedness, where you go out and tape the windows and buy the candles and you are not sure if it's going to come -- and if it does, if it's ever going to get back to normal,'' said Susan Doban, an architect who lives with her family on Bergen
title: In Brooklyn, Bracing for Hurricane Barclays

body: The Gotham column on Tuesday, about penalties for drivers who hit pedestrians in New York, misidentified the Brooklyn neighborhood where one pedestrian, Clara Heyworth, was killed. It is Fort Greene, not Prospect Heights.
title: Corrections

body: Roxana Sorina Buta, dark-eyed and lithe, hurried home from work as a waitress on May 24, scurrying through rain and 1:30 a.m. darkness toward the subway. She got to Broadway and stepped into the crosswalk when the light turned green. At the same time a New York City dump truck rumbled eastbound on 14th Street and turned south on Broadway. On the
title: GOTHAM; Reckless Drivers Who Hit People Face Few Penalties in New York

body: IN her senior year at New York University, Rachel Bishop left dorm living behind. Since then, she has always paid under $1,000 a month -- sometimes well under -- for rent. Ms. Bishop, 25, started out as one of five roommates in a two-bedroom in Williamsburg, Brooklyn . Two roommates doubled up in each of the bedrooms, and the fifth had ''a little
title: THE HUNT; Have Guitars, Will Party

body: IN New York's bar scene this fall, beer mugs and wineglasses will take a back seat to cocktail coupes. The recent deluge of wine bars and beer gardens seems to have abated a bit, but the mixology craze rages on. The iconic Lower East Side speakeasy Milk & Honey will move uptown and become less of a secret, while its old digs will don a new name,
title: FALL RESTAURANT PREVIEW; New Bars Shy Away From Serving It Neat

body: When the wife-and-husband team of Jennifer and Shane Covey opened their 28-seat East Village restaurant, Upstate , last July, the concept was monkishly minimal: beer and oysters. ''We're relatively uncomplicated people,'' Ms. Covey said, though she also said her husband used three types of beer glasses at home. Not that more complicated people have
title: AT THE TABLE | UPSTATE; Old Friends And Oysters

body: THIS morning, I grabbed a bowl from the cabinet, went outside and picked my breakfast of fresh figs . No, I'm not vacationing near the Mediterranean coast. Nor am I in California or the South. I'm at home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, where the fig tree in my tiny garden is covered in ripening fruit. I've had the tree for 15 years, but when the
title: A GOOD APPETITE; Italy to Brooklyn, Fig by Fig

body: IT took a while for Athanasios Biros to solve the mystery of his noisy upstairs neighbor. Mr. Biros, 35, who works for a bank, at first suspected a bartender with odd working hours lived above his studio in Greenwich Village. Then he heard a pounding noise at 7 in the morning. ''I just snapped,'' he said. He knocked on the door, and met his
title: Sleepwalk to Work

body: Gibran K. Brown and Jaie Jordan sat on the stoop of their brownstone, looking out over Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, as they do most warm evenings. In the distance, dust settled on the soccer pitch as players scattered after a game. Except for a jingling dog collar, the huffing of a passing jogger and the chorus of cicadas, the cooling air was
title: SUMMER NIGHTS; Savoring the Illicit Thrill Of a Glass of Something, Outside

body: Around TownMuseums and Sites Museum of the City of New York: 'Damn Yankees' (Wednesday) Robert Fleder, a former executive editor of Sports Illustrated, will talk about the Yankees with Dan Barry, a national columnist for The New York Times and author of ''Bottom of the 33rd,'' and other sportswriters. The event, beginning at 6:30 p.m., will also
title: Spare Times

body: Laura Friedman came up with a list of things she wanted to do before leaving Brooklyn for law school in California, and near the top was an outing at Coney Island. So the other day, she reveled in the restored Wonder Wheel and the Steeplechase roller coaster in Coney Island's spruced-up amusement parks and chomped on a cob of corn from one of its
title: Coney Island, Renewed but Recognizable

body: From a distance, it looks as if it could be an unusually large mailbox, or perhaps a doghouse almost three feet off the ground. Tucked under the shade of a tree and bolted into a sidewalk on St. Marks Avenue in Brooklyn, this wood box, 20 by 24 inches, turns heads as neighbors stroll by. Children are, of course, more willing to explore. On Monday,
title: Barely Bigger Than a Breadbox, but Teeming With Literary Treasures in Brooklyn

body: The City Room column in some editions on Saturday, about the opening of a pool in Brooklyn Bridge Park in Brooklyn Heights, misidentified the neighborhood of Clarissa Wertman, who was at the pool with a friend. She is from Crown Heights -- not Prospect Heights, where her friend lives.
title: Corrections

body: As they often do, Andrew Rausa and a few friends spent the evening of July 4 lounging barefoot on the front stoop of a friend's brownstone home in Brooklyn and enjoying a few beers. Escaping the indoor heat, Mr. Rausa and two friends sipped cans of Brooklyn Summer Ale; his girlfriend held an unopened bottle of a blueberry ale. When an unmarked
title: CITY ROOM; Debating if Gated Stoop Is a Legal Place to Drink

body: For much of the past century, Brooklyn was the Rodney Dangerfield of boroughs, known for its blue-collar style, for its funny accent and, of course, for getting no respect. Then came the brownstone homesteaders and the bohemian pioneers. They turned lunch-bucket warrens in Park Slope, Dumbo and Williamsburg into glamorous destinations, drawing a
title: As Brooklyn Gentrifies, Some Neighborhoods Are Being Left Behind

body: In the shadow of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and just a few yards from the dirt heaps of a dusty construction site, blue and yellow beach umbrellas bloomed. Classic songs like John Lennon's ''Imagine'' floated over an artificial beach stocked with white sand and beach chairs. Smiling teenagers handed out cupcakes and lemonade. And on Friday,
title: CITY ROOM; No Fanfare or Fights As a 'Pop-Up' Pool Opens in Brooklyn

Rather than making one evening-length dance, the artistic director Sarah A. O. Rosner created a versatile ''menu'' of 27 sections, from
title: The Listings

body: For months, people walking past Chase Manhattan Plaza in Lower Manhattan have gazed upon an empty two-acre expanse surrounded by fences and patrolled by private security guards. Although the plaza, located a block from the New York Stock Exchange, has been open to the public for decades, tall accordion-style fencing anchored with sandbags was
title: Suit Seeks Plans for Closed Public Plaza as Owner's Motives Are Questioned

body: Students at Public School 9 Teunis G. Bergen in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, started the summer with the grim news that they would lose four teachers next academic year unless parents raised $160,000 -- and soon. The principal of the school, Sandra D'Avilar, told the parent-teacher organization last month that she would have to cut the teaching
title: SCHOOLBOOK; With Fewer Poor Students, Schools See Budgets Shrink

body: TO date, no tour buses have been sighted outside Café Grumpy, the real-life coffee shop at 193 Meserole Avenue in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, where the fictional Hannah serves up lattes and attitude on the HBO series ''Girls,'' which concluded its first season last Sunday. But give it time. Bloggers and fans of Lena Dunham's breakout series, which
title: NOTICED; A Star Without Dialogue

body: Suddenly, Charles Barron has regained the ability to shock. The New York political world had long ago become accustomed to the incendiary words of Mr. Barron, a confrontational onetime Black Panther turned three-term City Councilman. His more outrageous remarks over the years, from calling Thomas Jefferson a pedophile to likening Gaza to a
title: In Brooklyn, a Longtime Provocateur Surges in a Primary Race for Congress

body: IF you are looking for temporary housing in New York City, you can bet that the amount of work it takes to find a place for a month or two is inversely proportional to how much you can afford to pay. At the upper end of the market, a few phone calls will land a fully furnished apartment designed for the Town Car set: executives on a short
title: GETTING STARTED; The Don't-Need-It-for-Long Apartment

body: THIRTEEN years ago, no one in Manhattan went to Brooklyn for dinner by choice. You had to dangle Peter Luger as bait, and a car service back to ''the city,'' or at least an escort to the subway. Then Emiliano Coppa and Anna Klinger, a Venetian and an American who had fallen in love in Italy and settled in Brooklyn, opened Al di Là in Park Slope.
title: HUNGRY CITY; In Crown Heights, Malfatti for the Trilbys

body: In the name of living his New York City life with as little environmental impact as possible, Colin Beavan embarked on a punishing project five years ago. He and his family stopped taking the elevator to their ninth-floor Manhattan apartment; they did their laundry by stomping on it in the tub; for about six months, they even went without
title: THE APPRAISAL; An Environmental Crusader's Newest Goal: Congress

body: The bike-share stations will be pliable, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said -- their assembly so simple that, if problems arise, docks can be removed without leaving a trace. And yet, with the program's first 420 proposed locations unveiled on Friday, proponents say New York has taken a step toward a watershed moment in the transportation history
title: City Unveils Locations of Bike-Share Stations

body: They may not be the luckiest people in the world, but Brooklyn people who want to see Barbra Streisand struck a jackpot of sorts Wednesday: the singer confirmed that she is returning to her home turf, to perform for the first time since she graduated from Erasmus Hall High School as a fiercely ambitious teenager and became, well, Barbra Streisand.
title: CITY ROOM; A Streisand Encore, 5 Decades Overdue

Not because the
title: DINING BRIEFS | RECENTLY OPENED; 606 R&D

body: Hakeem Jeffries, a state assemblyman, is the front-runner in the race for the Brooklyn Congressional seat held for 15 terms by Representative Edolphus Towns, with a $400,000 campaign chest. Winning would make him the representative of a heavily black district in a borough where blacks are the largest reliably Democratic ethnic group, and would give
title: The Power Players of New York: Brooklyn

body: For this special issue, the Metropolitan section asked the reporters who cover the New York region to identify the powerful figures on their beats, and to explain what gave them clout and where they fell on the chain of influence in New York. A separate article identifies those figures who earned the highest spot in our power pantheon: heavy

body: While interning two years ago at Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Karen Orlando would often gaze longingly from the roof of her apartment building in Prospect Heights to a lot below on Sterling Place. The three-quarter-acre site where a parking garage had once stood had degenerated into an empty, dirt-filled tract. ''It was starting to fill up with
title: CITY ROOM; In Vacant Lots and Yards, A Flower Business Grows

body: OPENING KIMCHI GRILL Phillip Lee of the Kimchi Taco truck opens a simple, contemporary-style restaurant. The chef Youngsun Lee, his original partner (no relation), is no longer involved, so it's up to Michael Calderon to cook the creative Korean fare: dishes like kimchi quesadillas, ssam buns with spicy pork or beef, and barbecued beef burritos.
title: Off the Menu

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Bronx Museum of the Arts: 'Baseball in the Bronx: Nine Innings of Bronx Baseball' (Friday through Sunday, and Monday) This show, under way through May 13, includes photographs of amateur and professional players over the years, as well as memorabilia of former players and talks and other events. On Friday at 3 p.m. the
title: Spare Times: Around Town

body: The battle over Atlantic Yards has already raged longer than the Civil War, with eight years of protests, petitions and lawsuits seeking to halt a project that promised to reshape the heart of Brooklyn. Even now, as the oyster-shaped basketball arena that will anchor a 22-acre housing and office complex rises against the low-slung Brooklyn skyline,
title: Impact of Atlantic Yards, for Good or Ill, Is Already Felt

body: A few years ago, Tatianna Kantorowicz, an aspiring filmmaker in her 20s and a Columbia University graduate student living on the Upper East Side, wanted to make a movie about teenagers coming of age in Manhattan. She had come to New York by route of her native Bogotá, Colombia, and Swiss boarding school, and maintained an interest in those
title: BIG CITY; A Killing, And Queries About a Life

body: A LINE of priests, chanting choir members, and altar girls and boys, all dressed in red and white robes, streamed down Duffield Street in Downtown Brooklyn last weekend, leading the Palm Sunday street procession at the Oratory Church of St. Boniface. Behind them were about 400 people, including elderly parishioners, young parents with toddlers in
title: Parish Without Borders

body: The pop singer-songwriter Ingrid Michaelson's latest release, ''Human Again,'' made its debut at No. 5 on the Billboard charts. As a fortuitous bit of executive-level preparation for her coming 28-date tour, she performed this month at the fund-raiser for President Obama hosted by Deepak Chopra and Russell Simmons at ABC Kitchen in Manhattan. Ms.
title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | INGRID MICHAELSON; The Joys of Couch Time

body: Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. Carl Allen-Rodney Whitaker Project (Friday through Sunday) The drummer Carl Allen and the bassist Rodney Whitaker have two recent albums on the Mack Avenue label, both suggestive of an urbane twist on hard bop. Their strong cohort includes Tim Green on alto saxophone, Eric Reed on
title: The Listings

body: Triangle Sports has occupied the same three-cornered site on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn since 1916. But in January, the store's owners put the 1,570-square-foot parcel on the market. What motivated them was the behemoth across the street -- the Barclays Center, the 19,000-seat arena where the Nets will play, and which is expected to open in just
title: In Barclays Center's Shadow, Awaiting What's Next

body: THE Cupcake Wars came to Public School 295 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, in October. The Parent-Teacher Association's decision to raise the price of a cupcake at its monthly bake sale -- to $1, from 50 cents -- was supposed to be a simple way to raise extra money in the face of city budget cuts. Instead, in a neighborhood whose median household income
title: 'It's Never Just About the Cupcake'

body: AT the height of the condo building boom in Manhattan, when it seemed as if a shiny new building was being announced every week, developers took a page from the motion picture industry and seized on star power to sell their projects. In the same way that George Clooney and Meryl Streep could be counted on to carry a picture, these brand-name
title: Boldface Buildings In the Cold Light of Now

body: 766 Classon Avenue (Sterling Place), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 230-9229, petezaaz.com. With all the Neapolitan ovens being installed around town, New Yorkers are eating a lot of new, but not much newfangled, pizza. One maverick is PeteZaaz, in Brooklyn. This narrow Prospect Heights shop with its cute takeout window is the work of Glen
title: DINING BRIEFS | RECENTLY OPENED; PeteZaaz

body: A cheer went up the other night at James, a popular Brooklyn bistro, as a triumphant waiter marched into the retro-tinged dining room bearing the new gold star of the New York City restaurant trade: a framed, blue letter ''A.'' As diners applauded, the waiter placed the letter grade in the restaurant's front window -- and removed the green ''B''
title: Bloomberg Defends Grading System Derided by Restaurateurs

body: An article on Jan. 14 about the competitive future of the New Jersey Nets misidentified the location of the team's new arena in Brooklyn, which will open later this year. It is on rail yards and other land in Prospect Heights and on a block in Park Slope; it is not in Downtown Brooklyn, although it is near that neighborhood. (The error also
title: Corrections

body: 124 Bedford Avenue (North 10th Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (347) 799-2743, allswellnyc.tumblr.com/. I am one of about 20 people who caught Nate Smith's monthlong run at Dean Street in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, and I'm glad I did. Mr. Smith, the former chef de cuisine of the Spotted Pig, was doing some very strong, well-considered gastropub
title: DINING BRIEFS | RESTAURANTS; Allswell

body: A THREE-BEDROOM house in Scarsdale for $500,000? It would have been unlikely five or six years ago when the market was on a roll, with many single-family houses selling at asking price, and with bidding wars not uncommon. But that is not the case anymore. Today, buyers on a limited budget like Chip and Katie Rich -- who had been determined to find
title: IN THE REGION | WESTCHESTER; Low-End Deals in High-End Places

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society: 'Fading Ads of Brooklyn' (Wednesday) Vintage advertisements that were put on brick walls around the city decades ago are still in plain sight, and some have survived for almost a century. The photographer Frank Jump will discuss the phenomenon of the fading ads and his endeavor to document
title: Spare Times

body: It's easy to fall in love with a neighborhood in New York. And given the high cost of housing, it's common to realize that you can't afford the home you want in the neighborhood you love. So, what to do? Your first instinct may be to look a few stops away on the same subway line, trading Williamsburg for Bushwick, for instance. Or you might choose
title: You're Priced Out. Now What?

body: Opening ALISON EIGHTEEN Alison Price Becker's return to the Manhattan restaurant scene after an absence of almost 10 years conjures memories of her previous restaurant, Alison on Dominick Street. The same chef, Robert Gurvich, is back, and the same designers, Asfour Guzy, have created the new Alison. But here, the velvet curtain at the entrance is
title: Off the Menu

body: NEWARK -- The question of where the Nets are headed as an organization and as a basketball team leads only to a host of potential destinations that range from exhilaration to dread, with an occasional detour into comic relief. Technically, and temporarily, the Nets are in Newark, on their way to a new home next season in Brooklyn. By all other
title: Brooklyn Awaits Nets, But Their Destination As a Team Is Unclear
